like from Friday to Thursday

Time goes in reverse. According to tradition, during the night between Thursday and Friday dreams tend to be prophetic.

It would be amusin to find out who will be next with her now, with whom will she have fun and whom, they kept guessin, she’ll make an orphan

explanatory structure
Shallow Reach

Sokolov himself explains that by the Volga river “there is a settlement called Melkovo [literally, small, fine], it stands on the bank of a stream pool, which local people call Melkovsky, but the location of Melkoplesovo [translated by Boguslawski as Shallow Reach] does not really exist” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

A reference to the Russian expression “Выше лба уши не растут” meaning that one has limits to what they can do.

We lugged him to Vygodoshchi

explanatory
Vygodoshchi

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

location setting Russia theme
islands of Tavern Dawn

In the original, Kabatskaya zarya. An island named Kabatsky exists by Dudinka on the Enisey river, while Zarya is a peninsula in Arctic Siberia. It could be a generic reference to Siberia. The former is mentioned in chapter 14 (R260/E196).

intratextuality location Russia
departed

That is, Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr. On a different level, one may read this as a reference to Sokolov’s mother and aunt who used to tell him stories about their native Siberia: “My aunt, my mother’s sister, mostly raised me. She was a woman of the old regime, strict. She graduated from a classical gymnasium in Novonikolaevsky and knew exactly how good gentlemen should behave. She read out loud beautifully, told miraculous stories, and sang Siberian songs” (Vrubel’-Golubkina, “Sasha Sokolov”).

religion bible intertextuality
Itil

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location setting foreign language
free patches

That is, the islands.

explanatory
durin the forest harvest

In June — the time of berry harvest.

time explanatory
Life Everlastin

Here used to refer to death. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

theme character intertextuality intratextuality
time of my death

Quotation from Mandel’shtam, “В Петрополе прозрачном мы умрем”; read the original here.

intertextuality
fussbustle

Fuss and bustle.

register/style
Pyotr

The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr’s name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

explanatory character intratextuality foreign religion
cripples

The word used in the original, kalika, indicates blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin caligae, Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. (Miller 27–28). Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 9 (R214/E112), chapter 10 (R223/E129), and chapter 11 (R230/E141). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif Russia foreign intratextuality
preferred a reliable rope to drudgery

Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr opts for suicide over drudgery.

explanatory
not high, upon verification, is our soarin

Throughout the novel, there is a tension between being pulled down toward the bottom of the river and a desire to rise up toward the firmament.

theme
Krylobyl

At this point, the reader understands that Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river, in Vydogoshch). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it was Krylobyl who advanced the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
sleepers

Linked to the ignis fatuus just recalled and due to the general atmosphere of the book, these “sleepers” are easily assimilated to the dead who are here invited by Krylobyl’ to wake up. In a Christian reinterpretation, Krylobyl is miraculously raising the dead.

the wandrin ones

Will-o’-the-wisp (ignis fatuus), a mythologized phenomenon well attested in European folklore.

intertextuality theme
Bygodoshch

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

time
accordin to the frozen price list

Sokolov explains: “A gravedigger gets more money for digging graves in winter, when the ground is frozen, than in warm seasons. Every cemetery has its own price tags. Ilya says that in that area gravediggers devised the idea of digging graves in advance, when there is no great need for them: there are not so many dead people in summer. They dig in summer and get money in winter, when people die more often, at high, ‘frozen’, read - winter, rates” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

location Russia character
belladonna berries

Boguslawski explains why he chose to translate the poisonous plant deadly nightshade as belladonna: “in Russian, it is called volch’ia iagoda (wolf berry). The word ‘belladonna’ is used here to avoid confusing the plant with the beneficial wolfberry (goji)” (“Annotations” 248). Plant motif.

motif
that dame

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

The Volga.

explanatory
tablets

This Biblical word (Moses’s Tablets of Stone) carries a relevant meaning for Sokolov, who also used it in the title of one of his essays, On Secret Tablets (1981). In this text, the writer retraces his literary destiny, wondering about the meaning of being an artist and a writer and suggesting that life often just follows what art has already predicted on “secret tablets.”

explanatory character
I went, warned

Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder. Here, he prophesizes.

religion character bible
Karaban

Vasily Karaban appears as the messenger who brings news of the phenomenon of Orina in the form of Everlastin’ Life or that Dame to the Volga community in which the novel is set. He is her first victim and, while he remains alive, he has shriveled up. His occupation, as Sokolov confirms, is unclear (personal communication, July 7, 2023). The name Karaban is of Turkic origin and can either be a surname or a nickname, a shortened version of Karabanov. It means “black mole” from “kara” (black) and “ban” (mole, birthmark). According to Turkic folklore, a black mole is a sign of happiness. Therefore, in the context of Between Dog and Wolf, it may be an ironic marker given Karaban’s fate (“Proiskhozhdenie familii Karabanova”).

character foreign folklore
crashbaret

A drinking establishment. Original Russia: кубаре (kubare). A mixture of kubarem (to fall head over heels) and the French “cabaret.” Customers, of course, will fall over and crash to the floor if they drink too much. The name of the establishment is literalized in this way. On Sokolov’s use of neologisms, see Brainina.

flask

Alcohol theme.

elms

motif
only greenish, ’cuz of the star

The starlight shifts the color and view. As Sokolov explains, he has no particular star in mind here. Rather, it’s a star with “an indefinite article” (personal communication, August 25, 2023).

explanatory
ginger

Blood (reddish) moon.

explanatory
Gybodoshchi

An anagram of Bydogoshch mentioned before. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

setting symbol theme
Gorodnishche

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting folklore intertextuality theme
unknown

An apparent allusion to Alexander Blok’s “Unknown Lady” (1906). The poem has certain resonances and overlap with Sokolov’s novel: drinking, truth, a mysterious woman.

intertextuality
splashhouse

Once again characters are associated with animals (here, with birds). The original word porkhalishche defines a place where birds are protected and free to bathe. Here, it is to be intended as the banya mentioned before. Animal-human motif.

motif explanatory
Life Everlastin

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен (paklen) and неклен (neklen) are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Neklina, Paklina). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

theme character intertextuality intratextuality
Karaban

Vasily Karaban appears as the messenger who brings news of the phenomenon of Orina in the form of Everlastin’ Life or that Dame to the Volga community in which the novel is set. He is her first victim and, while he remains alive, he has shriveled up. His occupation, as Sokolov confirms, is unclear (personal communication, July 7, 2023). The name Karaban is of Turkic origin and can either be a surname or a nickname, a shortened version of Karabanov. It means “black mole” from “kara” (black) and “ban” (mole, birthmark). According to Turkic folklore, a black mole is a sign of happiness. Therefore, in the context of Between Dog and Wolf, it may be an ironic marker given Karaban’s fate (“Proiskhozhdenie familii Karabanova”).

character foreign folklore
We had a swig

Alcohol theme.

theme
guzzlin

Alcohol theme.

theme
takin medicine, and not just any which way, but like pristipomas

Sokolov explains: “Often drinkers, as if to justify their predilection, joke at a party as follows: We do not drink, but cure ourselves, and not sometimes, but often, and we drink not a teaspoon, but a whole teapot. There is also a saying: he drinks like a fish. However, Ilya, a typical elegant talker and master of literary language, does not miss the opportunity to periphrase and combine these expressions: ‘takin medicine’ and ‘pristipomas’ is much more expressive than ‘we do not drink’ and ‘drink like a fish’” (personal communication, July 7, 2023). Animal motif. Alcohol theme.

theme motif language register/style phraseologism character
pristipomas

The word defines the fish Pomadasys, sometimes called boarfish; once again an animal is mentioned in the book. Sokolov explains that in the past this fish was called “pristipoma,” but then the prefix “pri” was substituted by “pro”: “This fish is found in all oceans, it is very tasty” (personal communication, July 7, 2023). Animal-human motif.

motif language
Мол

Colloquial: she says. This is a continuation of the very end of chapter 8 where Orina takes over the narrative (R212/E108). For an extended analysis of this part of the chapter, see Barbara Heldt’s “Female Skaz in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf.”

Разговорное: говорит. Продолжение конца главы 8, где Орина берет повествование в свои руки (R212/E108). Расширенный анализ этой части главы см. в статье Б. Хельдт “Женский нарратив в Между собакой и волком Саши Соколова” ( Barbara Heldt, “Female Skaz in Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf”).

register/style explanatory intratextuality character
гуляй

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that here in chapter 10 Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person,” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

Разговорное: развлекаться, отдыхать. Частое употребление глагола “гулять” связано с определением Орины в главе 10 как “гулящей”: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). В данном случае, “гулена” относится к пристрастию Орины к застольям и пиршествам, а “гулящая” указывает на ее беспорядочные романтические отношения.

intratextuality register/style
гуляй не хочу

Set expression: to your heart’s content, as much as you wish.

Устойчивое выражение: сколько душе угодно, сколько захочется.

phraseologism
эта бабуля жировку со мной делила

Barbara Heldt writes: “the girl [Orina] stands next to her granny, as in a medieval tableau of a beauty and a hag. Her youthful deprivations foreshadow old age and oblivion; the entire work is a kind of memento mori” (281).

Б. Хельдт пишет: “девушка [Орина] стоит рядом с бабушкой, как в средневековом полотне, изобращающем красавицу и старуху. Ее лишения молодости предвещают старость и забытье; произведение в целом является своего рода memento mori” (Heldt 281).

explanatory
бабуля

Colloquial: old lady.

Разговорное: пожилая женщина.

register/style
жировку

Dwelling, but also the term used to describe a place where hunting animals are fed. Animal-human motif. Sokolov adds that it’s a “document according to which payment for an apartment and amenities was made” (“Bol’shoe” 134).

Жилье, но этот термин также используется для описания места, где кормятся охотничьи животные. Мотив людей-животных. Соколов добавляет, что это “документ, по которому производилась оплата за квартиру и удобства” (Sokolov “Bol’shoe” 134).

motif location explanatory
старьевщица. Старым

explanatory
сороки

Magpie. The magpie is traditionally known as a thieving bird: “Regarded almost universally as a symbol of ill-omen,” the “magpie’s incorrigible addiction to pilfering has no doubt contributed to its unpopularity” (Rowland, Birds 103–104). Animal motif.

Сорока. Изображено ниже:

Сорока известна в народе как птица-воровка: “Почти повсеместно считающаяся символом дурного предзнаменования, сорока заслужила свою дурную славу в том числе благодаря своей склонности к воровству” (Rowland, Birds 103–104). Мотив животных.

folklore motif
грачики

Rook. Peter Tate writes: “Rather like ravens, rooks were formerly thought to play an important role in foretelling the future. […] In England […] rooks were believed to abandon both their nests and young prior to the departure or death of one of the family on whose land their rookery stood” (125–126). Perhaps simply coincidentally, these rooks would seem to foretell Orina’s tragic fate. Likewise, Tate mentions “an old belief that rooks escorted the souls of the righteous to heaven, a belief hinted at in the opening line of William Butler Yeats’ poem ‘The Cold Heaven’ (1916)” (126). Animal motif.

Грач. Изображено ниже:

П. Тэйт пишет: “Подобно воронам, грачи раньше считались предвестниками будущего. […] В Англии […] верили, что грачи покидают свои гнезда с птенцами перед приближением смерти в семье владельца земли, где они гнездовались” (Tate 125–126). Должно быть, по чистому совпадению, грачи будто бы предсказывают трагическую судьбу Орины. К тому же, Тэйт упоминает “древье поверье, согласно которому грачи провожали праведные души на небеса — поверье, которое нашло отражение в первой строке стихотворения Уильяма Батлера Йейтса ‘Холодные небеса’ (1916) (прочитать английский оригинал можно здесь, а русский перевод — здесь)”. Мотив животных.

Одуваны

Dandelions (usually in Russian they are defined by their diminutive, oduvanchiki). According to Gretchen Scoble and Ann Field, “Dandelions are a useful divinatory tool […] A girl who wants to know whether her sweetheart is thinking of her has merely to blow on a dandelion puff three times. If any seed stalks remains, that is proof positive that she is in his thoughts” (52). Plant motif.

Одуванчики (обычно употребляется в уменьшительной форме). Изображено ниже:

Согласно Г. Скобл и А. Филд, “одуванчики используются при гадании. […] Если девушка хочет узнать, думает ли о ней ее любимый, ей достаточно всего подуть три раза на одуванчик. Если на цветке осталось несколько семян-парашютиков, это подтверждение того, что она у него на уме” (Scoble and Field 52). Мотив растений.

sound rhythm
шлак

Slag is a by-product of used metals.

explanatory
Орина

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Орина мне говорит, будто я сам никогда не искал

Ilya interrupts Orina’s tale. Thus, this opening section could all be Ilya reporting Orina’s words in a long free direct speech. Heldt suggests the opposite: “the chief female character/s, who are variants of Orina, generally lie embedded in male narrative; here, however, she emerges to tell the story of her ‘life’ in ‘her own’ words” (279).

explanatory language
И мы лиса нашли на путях разрезанного. Видно, люди какие-нибудь посторонние изловили и привязали на гибель бечевками.

The fox who is killed on the railway is linked to Ilya who loses his leg in an accident on the tracks. In one version of this story, Ilya is tied up by the hunters (R259/E194). Animal-human motif.

intratextuality motif
зубы острые, хвост предлинный

Barbara Heldt observes of this scene in chapters 10 and 14: “The words about teeth and tail are repeated with the different that predlinnyi becoms dolgii, like the long memory of the event” (281).

explanatory
зубы острые, хвост предлинный

register/style

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that here in chapter 10 Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person,” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

To make chifir, which is an incredibly strong tea, known for its production in Soviet and post-Soviet prison settings and narcotic-like effects. It is made with several tablespoons of tea leaves or bags, which are not stirred and yield adenine and guanine in the boiling water.

explanatory
Папироску тогда раскурил и кожу на животе у меня прижигать собирается

Elena Kravchenko argues that as “the earth retains the traces of the plough — or its ‘industrialized’ version, the railway track — cutting though its surface, so does Orina. She is ‘marked’ by her lover, who, in order to obtain her ‘consent’, marks (or threatens to mark) her belly with cigarette burns. The sexuality of violence, manifest in marking and cutting through a surface, is also inherent in the violence of textuality” (The Prose 84). Railroad theme.

explanatory
И мужчина некоторый в соседнем бараке тогда проживал, кустарничал, под лестницей помещенье держал, кожей пахнул да ваксами. Дальше — больше, бабуля шкуру лиса дает: на, снеси, может, дядька этот тапти мягкие стачает тебе за так.

This event is later recounted in chapter 14 by Ilya, but there he is the furrier under the stairs (R255/E187). D. Barton Johnson summarizes: “Orina’s story has strange echoes in Il’ya’s later life. After parting from Orina, Il’ya sets himself up as a fur-dresser/cobbler […] Living in a room beneath the stairs, he befriends an old woman rag-picker and her mentally retarded ward whom he seduces when she brings him an animal hide. Their assignations take place in his room and under a beached boat, but the relationship ends when the pregnant girl takes up with the local sailors […] The fox-fur slippers made for Orina by her cobbler-seducer foreshadow the unknown article made by cobbler Il’ya for the slow-witted girl who is Orina’s successor” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 153–164). Olga Matich reads Sokolov’s novel as an extended response to Boris Pilnyak’s short story “Mother Earth” (1927), as it shares confusion between a wolf and a fox, a character name Arina, and a setting on the Upper Volga, among other similarities (“Sasha Sokolov” 312–313). Read the original here.

intratextuality
ваксами

Shoe polish. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

phraseologism time
мол

Colloquial: she said.

register/style
Оря

Diminutive form of Orina. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Оря гулена, а стала гулящая

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that here in chapter 10 Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person,” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

Разговорное: развлекаться, отдыхать. Частое употребление глагола “гулять” связано с определением Орины в главе 10 как “гулящей”: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). В данном случае, “гулена” относится к пристрастию Орины к застольям и пиршествам, а “гулящая” указывает на ее беспорядочные романтические отношения.

register/style
штиблет

Men’s shoes. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

register/style
Встрепенулись гуси в Илье

Orina’s body arouses Ilya. Beyond being considered a silly or stupid animal, the goose has other resonances. According to Beryl Rowland, the goose has been seen as “an erotic symbol for both sexes, because it was the bird of creation, whether in the male solar form of the gods or the female lunar form of the mother goddesses” (Birds 68). Connections between geese, sexuality, and foolishness appear several times in the novel (R154, 210, 221/E10, 106, 126). A reference to Ivan Krylov’s “Geese” (1811). Read the original here and a translation here. Animal-human motif.

motif intratextuality folklore
Встрепенулись гуси в Илье, Фомич

The narrative voice shifts back to Ilya.

explanatory structure
Илье

Ilya is Between Dog and Wolf’s protagonist and the author of what he calls the Zaitil’shchina, a long letter with epic traits (starting from its title) addressed to Inspector Pozhilykh in which he comments on the theft of his crutches (he has only one leg) and, more generally, describes life along the Volga River. Johnson defines Ilya’s letter as “semiliterate ramblings,” aptly suggesting the style and register the reader will encounter in the novel (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). However, this character expresses at the same time a highly poetic and imaginative gaze. Ilya frequently associates himself with the biblical prophet Elijah, a figure folklorically linked with thunderstorms and which in Slavic tradition acquired some of the characteristics of the pagan God of the sky and thunder, Perun. Ilya is closely related to other key characters of the novel: he describes his troubled relationship with Orina (alternatively called Maria and the Dame) with whom he has a son; in encountering Yakov (the focus of several chapters), he suggests the possibility of being his father. The Oedipal plot resulting from this triangle has been noted by scholars, such as Johnson, who writes that “the game warden Iakov lusts for his mother (reincarnate as a mentally defective girl) and kills his father-all without being aware of the identity of either” (“Twilight Cosmos” 644).

character intertextuality folklore
Фомич

Sidor (shortened form of Isidor), son of Foma. The inspector, Pozhilykh.

character register/style
растютей

Неологизм: может быть, от “тютя” и “быть в растютю”.

sound rhythm

Ilya thinks in fits and starts, slowly, puts his thoughts together pice by piece as if moving jerkily across water.

structure character
водомер

A water-strider. Appears three times in the novel (R210, 221, 254/E105, 126, 185). Zlata Kocić reads the three references to water-striders in Between Dog and Wolf as metatextual commentary on the stylistic movements of the novel: what appears to be jerky and chaotic actually reveals itself to be rhythmic and intentional (379). Animal-human motif.

A slightly outdated use of век (century) for жизнь (life).

Colloquial: rubbish, trash.

Colloquial/dated: new thing, clothes. Clothing motif.

register/style motif
фацеции

The Facetiae, the first printed joke book. Published by Poggio Bracciolini (1380–1459) in 1470.

foreign intertextuality
сквозь землю провидела

Set expression: to foresee. Similar to “как в воду глядеть” (to have second sight, have a gut feeling, as if one saw it in a crystal ball, lit: like looking into water).

phraseologism
трубила

High: to proclaim, pronounce.

register/style
Орина

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
гуленой

Colloquial: to have fun, to relax. The frequent use of the verb gulyat’ is linked to the fact that here in chapter 10 Orina is defined as gulyaschaya: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). In her case, “гулена” means “party person,” and “гулящая” is used to describe a woman with chaotic romantic relationships.

Разговорное: развлекаться, отдыхать. Частое употребление глагола “гулять” связано с определением Орины в главе 10 как “гулящей”: “была у нас Оря гулена, а стала гулящая” (R220/E124). В данном случае, “гулена” относится к пристрастию Орины к застольям и пиршествам, а “гулящая” указывает на ее беспорядочные романтические отношения.

register/style

register/style
канонерском

Gunboats. Used to transport machinery and weapons, as well as for protection and combat in smaller bodies of water and coasts. Boat motif.

motif
Илья

шмякнешься

молнией

ракушек

ракушек

intratextuality symbol theme motif bible religion
Всюду сумерки, повсюду вечер, везде Итиль

An echo of the novel’s opening lines with their ambiguous time and location.

time intratextuality location
Всюду сумерки, повсюду вечер, везде Итиль. Но там, где Зимарь-Человек на телеге супругу на карачун повез, лист сухой в самокрутку сворачивается на лету; под Городнищем, где речь про Егора, про Федора, — чистый декабрь; а на нашей на Волчьей — не верится даже — там иволга, там желна

A version of this entire passage appears in chapter 8 (R207/E100). Ilya describes how the rhythms of the river and the river’s flow vary depending on the location. Thus, the characters experience time differently depending on their position. Krylobyl explains the same near the end of the novel (R255/E186).

intratextuality time
сумерки

Between dog and wolf.

theme time
Итиль

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

location foreign language setting
Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

character intertextuality time motif
карачун

A mythological Slavic spirit who embodies death, frost, darkness, and cold. Associated with the winter solstice. Another name for the holiday Koliada.

time intertextuality folklore
самокрутку

Colloquial: a hand-rolled cigarette.

register/style
Городнищем

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting folklore theme intertextuality
про Егора, про Федора

The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr’s name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.”

Вновь, триада Егор/Федор/Петр. Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10) и не только, имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных “е/ё” и “о”.

character explanatory intratextuality
иволга

The golden oriole. The Russian name “ivolga” is homonymous with the word “vlaga” (moisture). It was once believed that the bird is a herald of rain. Here, however, the oriole is also chosen for the similarity to the name of the river Volga. Animal motif.

motif
желна

Black woodpecker. The woodpecker has traditionally played roles “as the god-sent bird in the ancient sacred grove; as the bird who […] cared for Romulus and Remus, and as the oracular bird of Mars, god of war” (Rowland, Birds 180). The black woodpecker in particular in folklore is often depicted as a “villain” who “acts contrary to the commands of the Almighty” in refusing to help create the world (Armstrong 96). Furthermore, “in a Russian legend, the woodpecker is a man whom God changed into a bird because he worked on Sunday” (97). Animal motif.

motif symbol folklore
Парко

Low: hot.

register/style
Парко, жарко

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
ракушкам

Ilya also writes about mussels at the end of chapter 1 (R157–158/E16). Associated with sex and Orina. Saint James the Great’s emblem features a mussel. Animal motif.

intratextuality symbol theme motif religion bible
геенне

Hell. The name Gehenna comes from the Valley of Hinnom, located outside Jerusalem. Also mentioned in chapter 12 (R244/E165).

religion foreign location intratextuality bible
Скорбно и Зимарь-Человеку жену губить

Sokolov comments: “Ilya compares Zimar’s grief over his wife’s imminent drowning to his pity for shells; he feels compassion for them, grieves for them, while eating them. It can be said that Ilya equates Zimar’s feelings with his own. As for Zimar’s wife, she does not appear anywhere else in the book, but in this small episode her role is significant” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Скорбь Зимаря по отношению к предстоящему утоплению супруги Илья сравнивает со своей жалостью по отношению к ракушкам, он соболезнует им, печалуется о них, поедая. Можно сказать, что Илья уравнивает чувства Зимаря и свои. Что касается жены Зимаря, то она нигде в книге больше не появляется, но в этом маленьком эпизоде ее роль дорогого стоит” (личная переписка, 7 июня 2023).

explanatory character
Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. According to the mythology, Orion fell in love with Merope (along with many other women) and raped her, similar to the story told here by Orina. Constellation-heavens motif.

но и он

Anagram.

Анаграмма.

Literary: old.

Зимарь

According to Boguslawski’s annotations, zimar’ refers to Andrei Voznesensky’s poem “Song-travesty from the spectacle ‘Antiworlds’” (1963) (“Annotations” 233). It combines the word zima (winter) with the ending of ianvar’ (January) to refer to the winter time. Perhaps a reference to the Orion constellation visible during the winter solstice. phraseologism time

Low: to intimidate.

register/style
Петра: что с Федором

His name gets mixed up again. Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Egor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

с концами

Set expression: forever, for good.

фефелы

Low: blockhead, dummy, dawdler.

Dated: lazy, inattentive.

register/style
Заводили, стало быть, счетовода сидни насчет повеситься

The hunters tease and dare Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr to hang himself after his time with the Dame. This conversation begins in chapter 8 (R207/E100–101) and also appears in Note XXXI (R268/E208).

intratextuality explanatory

Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr. Most likely, Fyodor/Petr/Yegor is not an accountant but a cashier.

explanatory character

Colloquial: couch potato, lazy-bones.

Разговорное: лентяи, бездельники.

register/style

Colloquial: they say.

register/style
хоть и Егорий

Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). He is alternatively called Fyodor and Yegor: the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer); here this link is also suggested by the adjective храбрый, brave, courageous. In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

character religion foreign intratextuality
бражников

Dated: drunkard, reveler. Hawkmoth. Associated with death due to the coloration on its back. Here, the hunters are taunting Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr, daring him to hang himself, so the connection is apt. Animal motif.

register/style motif
вскорости

Low: soon, before long.

register/style
косу

Braid, scythe, or sandback/spit. The ambiguity of the word “kosa” has a famous literary “predecessor” in Aleksandr Blok’s drama Balaganchik (The Puppet Show, 1906). The female character of Columbine has a “kosa” behind her back: either a hair braid or a scythe. The “mystics” warn Pierrot about her being Death, but he calls her his bride (“Я не слушаю сказок. Я — простой человек. Вы не обманете меня. Это — Коломбина. Это — моя невеста”; I don’t listen to fairy tales. I am a simple man. You will not deceive me. This is Columbine. This is my bride). The ambiguity is also stressed by the character of the Author who enters the scene and exclaims: “Я не признаю […] аллегорической игры словами: неприлично называть косой смерти женскую косу! Это порочит дамское сословие!” (I do not recognize […] such allegorical wordplay: it is indecent to call a woman’s braid a scythe of death! It denigrates a lady’s status!). In the end, Pierrot sadly discovers that this Columbine was just a “cardboard bride” (Она картонной невестой была). The crucial theme linking a woman’s love to death draws parallels between Sokolov’s novel and Blok’s Balaganchik, although there is a very long literary tradition that has developed this line (e.g., Eros and Thanatos; Catullus’s Odi et amo, I hate and I love). Read the original by Blok here.

language theme intertextuality
дабы

Archaism: in order to. (This word has seen a growth in usage in recent decades and is used in literary language.)

archaism register/style
синеву

That is, against the background of the darkening sky. This color is used several times in the novel in relation to the sky and atmosphere around the Itil (cf. R154, 157, 159, 196–197, 199, 222, 249, 277).

motif intratextuality
спроворил

Colloquial: to steal, pilfer.

register/style
дратве

А tarred or waxed thread for sewing shoes and other leather goods. Sewing theme. D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif theme
сторожа

Dated: guardians, guard duty.

register/style
независимом таком положении

Независимом means independent, but Sokolov is playing with the relationship to the word for “hang”: зависеть, завис.

sound play
фельдшера

German: Feldscher (“surgeon”) — a medical assistant, medical attendant, paramedic.

foreign character
Городнищ

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting folklore theme intertextuality
врачуй

Dated: to heal, treat.

register/style
Фельдшер

German: Feldscher (“surgeon”) — a medical assistant, medical attendant, paramedic.

foreign character
климатит

Low: having a good time.

register/style
быть, быть
