Повтор слова.

rhythm sound
Чего не обещаю — того не обещаю

Syntactic repetition.

Синтаксический параллелизм.

rhythm sound
лекарь

Dated/colloquial: doctor.

register/style character
отзвенел

To stop making noise, ringing. That is, he died, croaked.

language explanatory
горемыкалка

Colloquial: wretch, poor soul.

register/style
откуковал

To stop cuckooing. That is, he died. Animal-human motif.

explanatory language motif
дама его эта

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
рябам на смех

According to Ostanin, a play on the expression “курам на смех” (silly, stupid). Here, the meaning is “ridiculous, absurd, ungainly” (75).

phraseologism
с пятницы на четверг

Time goes in reverse. According to tradition, during the night between Thursday and Friday dreams tend to be prophetic.

intertextuality time folklore
салом словно бы по сусалам

Set expression: “мазать салом по мусалам” (to break a promise). Mixed with “дать (смазать) по сусалам” (to hit someone on the face).

phraseologism
салом словно бы по сусалам

Alliteration (s, l).

Аллитерация (с, л).

sound stylistic device
С кем, забавно бы выяснить, со следующим она побудет теперь, кого осчастливит, а кого, гадали, осиротит.

The Dame (Orina) will take various hunters, one by one. Upon their return, they will meet their death.

explanatory structure
мелкоплесовские

Sokolov himself explains that by the Volga river “there is a settlement called Melkovo, it stands on the bank of a stream pool, which local people call Melkovsky, but the location of Melkoplesovo does not really exist” (personal communication, June 7, 2023).

Соколов объясняет, что у Волги “есть поселок Мелково, он стоит на берегу плеса, который местные люди называют Мелковским, однако пункта Мелкоплесово в действительности нет” (личное сообщение, 7 июня 2023).

location Russia
сторожа

Dated: guardians, guard duty.

register/style
Вышелбауши

A reference to the expression “Выше лба уши не растут” meaning that one has limits to what they can do.

phraseologism
Федору

The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr’s name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Вновь, триада Егор/Федор/Петр. Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10) и не только, имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных “е/ё” и “о”.

character explanatory intratextuality religion foreign
физкультурной зимы

A harsh winter requiring strength and resources to survive and/or winter sport (ice skating).

explanatory time
не погнушались зазвать и меня

Ilya, the outsider sharpener, has a strained relationship with the hunters.

explanatory
Оттаранили его мы на Выгодощи

That is, buried.

explanatory
Выгодощи

As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

location setting Russia theme
тризну

A wake or funeral feast in ancient Slavic tradition held before cremation.

folklore
общий простор

That is, outside.

explanatory
Кабацкой Зари

An island named Kabatsky exists by Dudinka on the Enisey river, while Zarya is a peninsula in Arctic Siberia. It could be a generic reference to Siberia. The former is mentioned in chapter 14 (R260/E196).

location Russia intratextuality
отзывался всегда отчаливший.

Alliteration.

Аллитерация.

stylistic device sound
отчаливший

Colloquial: the departed. That is, Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr. On a different level, one may read this as a reference to Sokolov’s mother and aunt who used to tell him stories about their native Siberia: “My aunt, my mother’s sister, mostly raised me. She was a woman of the old regime, strict. She graduated from a classical gymnasium in Novonikolaevsky and knew exactly how good gentlemen should behave. She read out loud beautifully, told miraculous stories, and sang Siberian songs” (Vrubel’-Golubkina, “Sasha Sokolov”).

register/style character self-reference
нежели

Dated: than, in comparison with.

Novgorodian pirates who operated along the Volga River, the eastern part of Scandinavia, and north of the Ural mountains in 12th-15th century. Mentioned in Note XXIII (R231/E142).

sound rhythm
Итиль

The Tatar name of the river Volga. The title of Ilya’s letter “Zaitil’shchina” is derived from this version of the river’s name. Ostanin also suggests a sound link between the rivers Itil’ and Lethe (Leta), the river of oblivion and forgetting, which also plays a major role in Sokolov’s first novel, A School for Fools (10).

stylistic device sound
Жизнь Вечную

Here, used to refer to death. Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character theme intertextuality intratextuality
кануть

Dated: to fall, sink, vanish, disappear.

register/style
ничего, ничего

Anadiplosis.

Анадиплосис.

sound stylistic device rhythm
любому дяде троюродный я плетень

Ostanin writes: “about a very distant relation” (76).

explanatory
смертная година

Quotation from Mandel’shtam, “В Петрополе прозрачном мы умрем”; read the original here.

intertextuality
година

Poetic: time, year.

register/style time
замешкалась

Colloquial: to dawdle, tarry, loiter, linger, be late.

резоны

Colloquial/dated: reason, consideration.

register/style
лямку тянешь

Set expression: to drudge, pull weight, toil. Literally “to pull the strap.” A set expression meaning to labor with great difficulty. It is usually associated with Repin’s painting “Burlaki”.

phraseologism intertextuality
Петра

The Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr trio again. As seen in chapter 1 (R154/E10) and elsewhere, Pyotr’s name (not necessarily identity) constantly alternates with Yegor and Fyodor. Again, a random assignment of names to characters. In this case, the choice seems to be guided by the presence of the vowels “e/ë” and “o.” Pyotr/Fyodor/Yegor. Pyotr, “one smart aleck from Sloboda” (R173/E43), is Pavel’s uncle and is sent by his nephew in Gorodnishche to find yeast (when the story is retold in chapter 14, it is the uncle asking Pavel to get yeast). The name Pyotr, from Greek, means “stone.” The apostle Peter (Simon Peter), in origin a fisherman, is considered the first Christian Pope. Peter denied Jesus three times during the events of the crucifixion, as Jesus had predicted (see Matthew 26:69–75). Fyodor (Theodore) means “God’s gift.” The name Egor is a variation of the name Georgy (George), from the Greek “farmer.” He was immortalized as a saint through the legend of the Dragon (Saint George the Dragon-slayer). In chapter 10 this character is challenged to hang himself, which results in his suicide.

Вновь, триада Егор/Федор/Петр. Как и в главе 1 (R154/E10) и не только, имя Петр (но не обязательно личность Петра) чередуется с именами Егор и Федор. В очередной раз, присвоение героям случайных имен. Здесь выбор обусловлен присутствием гласных “е/ё” и “о”.

explanatory character intratextuality foreign religion
калек

A name given to blind wanderers who sing spiritual poems. Originally, the word did not refer to disabled or crippled beggars, as it does now, but rather to wanderers who visited holy places and sang songs. The term is derived from the Latin caligae,. Since these wanderers often lived off of alms in the towns they visited (and occasionally settled in), the term took on the meaning of a disabled person who does the same in its modern usage. (Miller 27–28) Also mentioned in Note XVIII (R204/E96), chapter 8 (R209/E103), and chapter 9 (R214/E112). D.B. Johnson has identified more than twenty different types of shoes across Sokolov’s three novels: “bashmaki, botforty, boty, botinki (polubotinki), cheboty, chizmy, chubury, galoshi (kaloshi), gety, ichigi, kedy, klogi, lapti, mokrostupy, obuvi (obuvki), sapogi, sandalii, tapochki (polutapochki), shlepantsy, shtiblety, tapti, tufli, valenki. The list may easily be extended with appurtenances such as socks, stockings, footcloths, gaiters, skates, crutches, and artificial legs” (“The Galoshes Manifesto” 156). Regarding Between Dog and Wolf, he notes that Ilya’s last name immediately evokes Cinderella’s vair slippers. Johnson observes that “the footwear motif is Sokolov’s tribute, both conscious and unconscious, to the tradition in Russian literature represented by his predecessors – Ivan Bunin and Valentin Kataev” (179). In an interview with A. and N. Voronel’, Sokolov calls Bunin, along with Gogol, his “contemporaries, collaborators along a chain, older masters” (Voroneli, “Ia khochu” 184). Shoe motif.

motif Russia foreign intratextuality
лямке веревку надежную предпочли

Yegor/Fyodor/Pyotr opts for suicide over drudgery.

explanatory
не высокого мы, на поверку, парения

Throughout the novel, there is a tension between being pulled down toward the bottom of the river and a desire to rise up toward the firmament.

theme
на поверку

Set expression: indeed, as a matter of fact.

phraseologism
Крылобылка

At this point, the reader understands that Krylobyl (here named through his diminutive) is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river, in Vydogoshch). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it was Krylobyl who advanced the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it will be Krylobyl in chapter 14 who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character register/style intertextuality intratextuality
вещий

Poetic: seer.

register/style
восстал

Dated/high: to rise, stand, get up. He experiences Christ’s resurrection. This “Christian” resurrection is described through poetic lexicon, unusual for Ilya’s speech/writing.

register/style religion language
светозарный

Poetic: radiant, illuminated, bright.

register/style
мурашах

Colloquial: small ant, small insect. Here: shivers, goosebumps. Animal motif.

motif register/style
блудящих

A variation of “блуждающие огни,” will-o’-the-wisp (ignis fatuus), a mythologized phenomenon well attested in European folklore.

language folklore
спящие

Linked to the ignis fatuus just recalled and due to the general atmosphere of the book, these “sleepers” are easily assimilated to the dead who are here invited by Krylobyl’ to wake up. In a Christian reinterpretation, Krylobyl is miraculously raising the dead.

быгодощенские

That is, the people of the cemetery (the undertakers). In chapter 1, Ilya mentions the village of Bydogoshch, of which Bygodozhd’ could be an ironic variant (-dozhd’ meaning “rain”) (R158/E16). As Sokolov explains, there is no relation between this location and the Polish town of Bydgoszcz (personal communication, June 7, 2023). It is rather a misspelling of the village (and lake) of Vidogoshch by the Volga River, near Tver’. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

time
по мерзлому ценнику

Sokolov explains: “A gravedigger gets more money for digging graves in winter, when the ground is frozen, than in warm seasons. Every cemetery has its own price tags. Ilya says that in that area gravediggers devised the idea of digging graves in advance, when there is no great need for them: there are not so many dead people in summer. They dig in summer and get money in winter, when people die more often, at high, ‘frozen’, read - winter, rates” (personal communication, August 21, 2023).

Соколов объясняет: “Могильщик получает зимой, когда земля мерзлая, больше денег за копку могил, чем в теплое время года. На каждом кладбище свои ценники, иначе сказать - прейскуранты. Илья рассказывает, что в той местности могильщики придумали копать могилы впрок, заранее, когда в них нет большой надобности: ведь летом покойников бывает не так много. Копают летом, а получают деньги зимой, когда люди умирают чаще, получают по высоким, мерзлым, читай - зимним, расценкам” (личная переписка, 21 августа 2023).

Bookish: to express an opinion in advance, to express an idea about what will happen to someone, or something in the future; to predict.

Книжное: заранее высказать мнение, соображение о том, что произойдет с кем-, чем-л. в будущем; предсказать.

register/style
чаша и до тебя не дошла

Sokolov affirms that this expression is a “phraseologism of Biblical origin”: “In the olden days, it was customary to drink from the same cup at a feast, passing it around in a circle, thus strengthening friendship. [Here] it is a warning of trouble to come, of course” (personal communication, August 25, 2023).

Соколов считает это выражение “фразеологизмом библейского происхождения”: “В старину был обычай пить в застолье из одной чаши, пуская ее по кругу: так крепилась дружба. Как бы чаша и до тебя не дошла - это, конечно, предупреждение о грядущей неприятности” (личная переписка, 25 августа 2023).

register/style
Крылобыл

Krylobyl is a key character dwelling in the world of the dead (living on the other shore of the Itil’ river). It is not surprising given his “speaking name” formed by the words “krylo” (wing) and “byl” (was, used to be). He is a hypostasis of an angelic creature guiding Ilya in his wanderings and suggesting to him ideas and reflections: in chapter 4 it will be Krylobyl who advances the idea of the origin of the “zhe” letter; it is Krylobyl in this chapter who Ilya describes as a “know-it-all” who “instructs,” the one “whom I trust, whom I praise.” In a sense, Krylobyl is Ilya’s Virgil or, even, Beatrice in his wandering across this very special Inferno, Purgatorio, and Paradiso. Toward the end of the novel, he will be addressed by the narrator in chapter 16 (R275/E220) and by Ilya in chapter 17 as “Fedot Fyodorov” (R279/E227).

character intertextuality intratextuality
ягоды волчьей

Literally: wolf berry. A collective name for several plants, including the belladonna or deadly nightshade, that bear poisonous or toxic fruit. Plant motif. Animal motif.

motif
Калуга

Kaluga, the administrative center of the Kaluga Oblast. Located on the Oka River.

character Russia location
будьте бдительны

According to Boguslawski, a reference to Julius Fučík’s final lines in his Notes from the Gallows: “People, I loved you. Be on guard!” (“Annotations” 248).

intertextuality
бдительны

Literary: vigilant, watchful.

register/style
сыздетства

Low: from childhood.

register/style
сыздетства на нее я зарился, но терпел, а сегодня увидел куст — и не вытерпел, крушина спелая, крупная, да и кручина моя велика

A sort of reinterpretation of Eve’s forbidden fruit story.

explanatory intertextuality religion bible
зарился

Colloquial: to hanker after, set one’s eyes on, desire.

register/style
крушина

The Frangula genus of shrubs and small trees. Also known as alder buckthorn. Plant motif.

motif
крушина спелая, крупная, да и кручина

Paronomasia.

Парономазия.

sound stylistic device
кручина

Poetic: woe, grief, anguish. Echo of крушина.

register/style sound play
побаловались

To frolic, goof around. Colloquial: to have sex.

register/style
И се

Dated: lo.

register/style
копыта

Hooves. Animal-human motif.

motif
не фартит

Colloquial: bad luck.

register/style
лещ

Common bream, a freshwater fish. Animal motif.

motif
нерест

Spawning. Animal motif.

motif
дама эта

Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

character intertextuality intratextuality theme
Фомич

Sidor (shortened form of Isidor), son of Foma. The inspector, Pozhilykh.

character register/style
Кто-то явится, так и знай

Interpretation of the dream (eggs in dreams are often meant to suggest a forthcoming visit - along with renewal, birth, a new idea, etc.).

explanatory symbol
выхромал

Ilya limps due to his missing leg.

explanatory
бирюзовая

Turquoise.

explanatory
други

Dated/dialectical: same as друзья (friends).

register/style
скрижалях

Dated: scroll, tablet, table, annal. This Biblical word (Moses’s Tablets of Stone) carries a relevant meaning for Sokolov, who also used it in the title of one of his essays, On Secret Tablets (1981). In this text, the writer retraces his literary destiny, wondering about the meaning of being an artist and a writer and suggesting that life often just follows what art has already predicted on “secret tablets.”

register/style religion bible self-reference
Ее

The Volga.

explanatory
аз есмь

Archaism from Church Slavonic: I am.

register/style archaism
ямина

Colloquial: same as яма (pit).

register/style
ямина долговая

A debtor’s prison. Also known as “долговая тюрьма.”

location language
Ты

explanatory religion

explanatory religion
особа некая

Orina.

explanatory character
через пеньколоду

Set expression: slipshod, topsy-turvy, half-assed.

phraseologism
Я потек, упредил

Ilya is frequently compared—by the narrator and by himself—to the prophet Ilya/Elijah, who is commonly associated with lightning and thunder. Here, he prophesizes.

character religion bible
через пень-колоду

Set expression: slipshod, topsy-turvy, half-assed.

phraseologism
препожалует

Colloquial: to arrive, come.

register/style
кубарэ

Unusual (and mockingly foreign) word. It may derive from the word “kubar’”, informally used by students of the naval academy to define a ship cabin.

Необычное (и мнимо-иностранное) слово, наверное от разговорного морского термина “кубарь”, каюта.

foreign neologism location
Карабан

Vasily Karaban appears as the messenger who brings news of the phenomenon of Orina in the form of Everlastin’ Life or that Dame to the Volga community in which the novel is set. He is her first victim and, while he remains alive, he has shriveled up. His occupation, as Sokolov confirms, is unclear (personal communication, July 7, 2023). The name Karaban is of Turkic origin and can either be a surname or a nickname, a shortened version of Karabanov. It means “black mole” from “kara” (black) and “ban” (mole, birthmark). According to Turkic folklore, a black mole is a sign of happiness. Therefore, in the context of Between Dog and Wolf, it may be an ironic marker given Karaban’s fate (“Proiskhozhdenie familii Karabanova”).

character foreign folklore
чекушки

Colloquial: a small bottle of vodka. Alcohol theme.

theme register/style
вдрябезги

Ostanin cites this as a variant of вдребезги (smithereens) (77).

language register/style
Будет вам

Set expression: enough, stop.

phraseologism
бражничать

Colloquial: to revel, carouse, rave, drink heavily.

register/style
в треволнении

Dated: in profound anxiety.

register/style
Тихо образовалось

The place gets quiet in a moment.

explanatory
глухонемых

The deaf-mutes’ shelter.

location
ильмами

Elms. Plant motif.

motif
пепелища

Burning fire.

explanatory

Dated: washhouse, laundry.

register/style
только в зелень ударяет из-за звезды

The starlight shifts the color and view. As Sokolov explains, he has no particular star in mind here. Rather, it’s a star with “an indefinite article” (personal communication, August 25, 2023).

explanatory
рыжая

Blood (reddish) moon.

explanatory
рыжая. И по рыжей

Anadiplosis.

Анадиплосис.

rhythm sound
Гыбодощи

An anagram of Bydogoshch mentioned before. D.B. Johnson suggests that, while the living dwell in Gorodnishche, Bydogoshch is home for the dead (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209).

setting theme symbol
Городнищу

The main setting of the novel: a fictional town on the banks of the Volga River. Also called Gorodnishchi. Derived from the words for town (gorod) and beggar (nishchii). It is the “town of beggars.” Olga Matich writes: “If School for Fools was written against the background of youth prose, Sokolov’s next novel Between Dog and Wolf may be read as the author’s response to village prose, the literary rage of the seventies” (“Sasha Sokolov” 310). Vadim Kreid observes that Gorodnishche, a barracks village of beggars and thieves, resembles an “Anti-Kitezh” (Kitezh being the legendary, mythical city in Russian folklore that only the pure-hearted will have the chance to reach). In Gorodnishche, however, thieves rob beggars, while beggars beg thieves (“Zaitil’shchina” 213). According to Johnson, the living dwell Gorodnishche, while the dead reside on the other side of the river, in Bydogoshch (“Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 209). Johnson also mentions a statement by Sokolov himself: “Sokolov reports that the name is a blend of the dissolute eighteen-century town of Gorodnya described by A. N. Radishchev in his Journey from Petersburg to Moscow and a nearby town called Gorodishche. Thus the time layers of the sixteenth century, the eighteenth century, and a mythic present are all superimposed upon each other – a characteristic technique in the novel” (217).

location setting folklore intertextuality theme
плесом

Stream.

explanatory
незнакомая

An apparent allusion to Alexander Blok’s “Unknown Lady” (1906). The poem has certain resonances and overlap with Sokolov’s novel: drinking, truth, a mysterious woman.

intertextuality
Поначалу

Colloquial: same as сначала (at first).

register/style
порхалище

Once again characters are associated with animals (here, with birds). Porkhalishche defines a place where birds are protected and free to bathe. Here, it is to be intended as the banya mentioned before. Animal-human motif.

explanatory motif
Вечная Жизнь

This expression may be intended here as “it is Death already,” “I was dead already.” Orina, along with her variants, is the primary female character in the novel. In a sense, she is the only female figure in Between Dog and Wolf. As D.B. Johnson summarizes, the “promiscuous heroine Orina-Mariia is a train dispatcher, a princess in her dispatcher’s tower, who entertains her coworkers in her bed. Some of her orgiastic trysts take place near the train tracks to which her lovers tie her meddling husband Il’ia. Orina, in at least one time dimension, is killed by a train as she belatedly tries to save Il’ia who loses his leg” (“Twilight Cosmos” 647). Ilya is obsessed with this woman, and this passion “is the ultimate source of the woes that befall Il’ia, the itinerant grinder. It is his passion for the faithless slut Orina that brings about his misfortunes: the loss of his leg, his wandering life as a drunken grinder, and the grisly events that lead to his death” (643). Orina, alternatively called Maria, exists in the book also in another version, as ta dama, that dame, “a mysterious woman who appears along the river seeking Il’ia and, failing to find him, takes away a new lover each time […]. Her chance lovers return days later, sexually depleted and without interest in life. They usually die by their own hand” (645). In this figure (which embodies “virtually all female figures in the book,” D.B. Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 211), Sokolov merges two of his major literary themes: sex and death. Thus, Orina, Maria, that dame (ta dama, ta devochka, ta bobylka, ta babulya — all linked by the demonstrative “ta”), “Life Everlastin,” and death in general make up a unique polymorphic character. Smith notices that this female figure “does not appear at all in the verse. The episode of the sexual encounter between this figure and the sailors, which reoccurs obsessively in the prose, is correspondingly absent from the verse passages” (333). Olga Matich suggests the existence of a literary subtext for Sokolov’s novel: “Pilniak’s lesser known story Mother Earth (Mat’ syra zemlia 1927) about the violent confrontation between a naive young Bolshevik and an archaic Volga peasant community at the time of the Civil War. It is a kind of love story between the city-bred Bolshevik and the horse-tanner and young earth mother Arina, impaled by the Cossacks in one of the story’s many violence-ridden episodes. A variation on the Scythian juxtaposition of nature and culture, the story also depicts Arina’s maternal love for a fox cub, whom she tries to tame, thinking it is a wolf” (“Sasha Sokolov and His Literary Context” 312). The name Orina may also carry an echo of Pushkin’s famous nurse Arina Rodionovna (Toker 353). Mario Caramitti proposes three recurring hypostases of ta dama across Sokolov’s novels: a first hypostasis is that of a “mysterious woman carrying an obscure menace and/or sexual temptation”; a second hypostasis is that of an “apparently better defined and concrete woman being the object of desire for the main character”; and the third hypostasis is that of a “child-woman, often mentally retarded, often victim of violences, who touches upon a slightly more sublimated erotic sphere” (“Amore e morte” 114). Caramitti also adds that in the novel one of ta dama’s victims, before or after committing suicide, explicitly calls her “вечная жизнь” (Life Everlastin): “it is precisely in the coitus with eternity, in a region of oblivion that it is most difficult to place on this side or on the other side of the Lethe, that the male protagonist finds the widest surface of contact with this protean female entity of now vast symbolic implications” (118). Among Orina’s many lovers and among the men who take advantage of her, there is also Yakov, her son, who is in a way “re-enacting the role of the lame Oedipus” (Johnson, “Sasha Sokolov’s Between Dog and Wolf and the Modernist Tradition” 212). In chapter 14, Orina’s patronymic is said to be “Ignat’evna” (daughter of Ignatii): the name Ignatii possibly comes from the Latin “ignis” (fire) (R258/E190). Given that Orina is depicted here through her lust, such a patronymic seems apt. Her last name is said to be alternatively Neklina and Paklina (Spacklin, in translation): “You were called around the barracks Orina Neklina, and to whom do you belong now, to what kind of, let’s suppose, Spacklin, ah?” (R246/E169). On the border with Ukraine, close to Mariupol’ and to Chekhov’s hometown Taganrog, there is Rostov district named Neklinovsky. Paklia and paklina are regional terms indicating different things: a left-handed person, an unhandy and clumsy person, a bony hand, a piece of hemp or coarse fiber, messy hair. The terms паклен and неклен are named for the Tatar maple (note the slight differences in the spelling between the tree names and Orina’s surnames: Неклина, Паклина). As Sokolov explains, “Apparently, the author of the Notes and Ilya know or have heard about a man named Paklin. Ilya says that Arina’s last name was Neklina, probably after one of her men. And now, years later, Ilya assumes, she lives with someone else, whose last name suggests to him the tree’s other name” (personal communication, July 7, 2023).

Карабан

Vasily Karaban appears as the messenger who brings news of the phenomenon of Orina in the form of Everlastin’ Life or that Dame to the Volga community in which the novel is set. He is her first victim and, while he remains alive, he has shriveled up. His occupation, as Sokolov confirms, is unclear (personal communication, July 7, 2023). character foreign folklore
Приняли

To drink. Alcohol theme.

explanatory theme
хлещем

Colloquial: to guzzle down a liquid. Alcohol theme.

register/style theme
лечимся, и не какнибудь, а как простипомы

Sokolov explains: “Often drinkers, as if to justify their predilection, joke at a party as follows: We do not drink, but cure ourselves, and not sometimes, but often, and we drink not a teaspoon, but a whole teapot. There is also a saying: he drinks like a fish. However, Ilya, a typical elegant talker and master of literary language, does not miss the opportunity to periphrase and combine these expressions: ‘takin medicine’ and ‘pristipomas’ is much more expressive than ‘we do not drink’ and ‘drink like a fish’” (personal communication, July 7, 2023). Animal motif. Alcohol theme.

Соколов объясняет: “Нередко любители выпить, как бы оправдывая свою склонность, шутят в застолье примерно так: Не пьем, но лечимся, и не иногда, а часто, и принимаем не по чайной ложке, а по целому чайнику. Имеется и такая поговорка: Пьет, как рыба. Однако, типичный краснобай и мастер художественного слова, Илья не упускает возможности перифразировать и скомбинировать эти выражения: не хлещем и простипома куда выразительнее, чем не пьем и рыба” (личная переписка, 7 июля 2023).

language phraseologism character register/style motif theme
простипомы

The word defines the fish Pomadasys, once again an animal is mentioned in the book. Sokolov explains that in the past this fish was called “pristipoma,” but then the prefix “pri” was substituted by “pro”: “This fish is found in all oceans, it is very tasty” (personal communication, July 7, 2023). Animal-human motif.

Род рыб; еще раз упоминается животный в повествовании. Соколов объясняет, что в прошлом эта рыба называлась “пристипома,” однако “народ решил, что про лучше, чем при. Эта рыба водится во всех океанах, очень вкусная” (личная переписка, 7 июля 2023).
